Doug Harris (Josh Gad) has a good job and is marrying a woman (Kaley Cuoco-Sweeting) way out of his league. Unfortunately Doug doesn't have any male friends close enough to be best man or grooms men. He lies about this to his future wife which forces him to hire them through Best Man Inc. employing the services of quick thinking golden tongue Kevin Hart. Hart hires a group of seven misfits to fill in. Doug and Hart bond during this time, while the film pays little attention to Kaley Cuoco-Sweeting, in what seems to be a bad role for her.

I couldn't help think that the role of Doug Harris would have been better played by a younger Jonah Hill. Kevin Hart was hit and miss during the film with the low point being the dog/peanut butter scene which was juvenile stupid. What were the writers? 14 years old? A good film for those that like dumb sex comedies that pretend to be meaningful.

This is a buddy/ odd couple comedy movie.

It's mildly entertaining without being particularly memorable.

What is it about? Doug (Josh Gad) is a hard working successful attorney who is getting married to Gretchen (Kaley (Big Bang Theory) Cuoco-Sweeting). He's having trouble finding a best man, so he engages Jimmy (Kevin Hart), a smooth talking professional best man for hire. We follow their journey to wedding day.

Is this a funny movie? I thought it had its moments. Messrs Hart and Gad try hard to extract humor from their characters' unusual relationship. Ms Cuoco-Sweeting's role is relatively minor, although it is pivotal to the twist at the end of the movie.

Is it worth seeing? I thought it was mildly entertaining as a light comedy entertainment, but I wouldn't give it a second viewing.

The Wedding Ringer was an enjoyable comedy to kick off the year with. It stars Kevin Hart as Jimmy Callahan, owner of TBM, Inc, or, to insiders, The Best Man, Inc. Jimmy offers "best man" services to grooms that find themselves lacking in the friend department, but is quick to remind his clients that any relationship they may have is strictly business. Doug Harris (Josh Gad) finds himself in a similar situation when he gets engaged to Gretchen (Kaley Cuoco-Sweeting) and can't find anyone to be a groomsman, let alone his best man. He's lied to Gretchen about his 8 friends that will fill up his side of wedding party, and he doesn't want to come clean because he knows that Gretchen is out of his league and coming clean about his lack of friends isn't even a possibility. With 10 days left before the wedding, Gretchen and Doug's wedding planner Edmundo (Ignacio Serricchio) becomes wise to Doug's lies and refers him to Jimmy. Jimmy ultimately agrees to pretend to be Doug's best man, Bic Michum, along with putting together 7 groomsmen, an impossible feat known in the business as The Golden Tux.

Overall, I thought this movie was really funny, with several hilariously memorable scenes. If you like Kevin Hart in general, I'm pretty sure you'll enjoy this movie. Similarly, if you liked a Think Like A Man or Think Like A Man Too, you'll find some similar faces in the movie, especially with that of Jimmy's assistant, Doris (Jenifer Lewis, or Loretta from the Think movies).

I read an interesting interview with Jeremy Garelick, one of the screenwriters who penned the script (and the director) for The Wedding Ringer, and he said that he originally wrote the part of Jimmy for Vince Vaughn about 10 or so years ago. Instead of the studio making this movie, however, a pitch for Wedding Crashers ended up being green-lit and turned into a script and then movie instead. In the interview, Garelick was asked if he had to change the script a lot to adapt it to a nerdy white guy hiring a black guy to be his best man, versus Vince Vaughn. He basically said that the underlying message of the film was friendship, not race, so there wasn't anything really to address or change. I agree with that and thought it was a funny movie with lots of laughs, but the heart of the movie was about friendship.

This movie did a great job of overcoming a big problem that many comedies fall victim to - the third act slump. Usually when a comedy tries to wrap up the plot and bring it toward a resolution, the movie tends to drag and be too serious without many laughs as the main character is coming clean or learning his lesson, or something similar. It's hard to keep the right balance of heart and seriousness, while still staying funny. For this movie, obviously you can guess that Doug will eventually have to come clean, or maybe Jimmy and Doug will really become friends, but the movie kept moving and stayed consistently funny throughout, which is a feat I don't see too often.

Overall - I laughed hard and loud throughout most of the movie and would definitely recommend it. It was a fun, funny movie.

Sony releases a comedy about a groomsmans desperate attempt to find a best man and fellow friends to attend his wedding. Doug Harris is about to marry the love of his life until he realizes that he doesnt have friends to join in. Doug reaches out to Jimmy Callahan whos business is to find his clients groomsmen but with a price. The film stars Kevin Hart and Josh Gad in a film about two people who find friendship in the unlikeliest of ways.

I have a lot of respect for Kevin Hart because hes one of those actors who can really make audiences laugh. Hes very fun to watch because of his ability to just meld with characters and bring out the best in them. So was the case with The Wedding Ringer as he plays Jimmy Callahan who does business with Doug (Josh Gad) and has knock out loud moments to the point of absurdity. And you have to give credit to Josh Gad who has good chemistry with Hart throughout the movie. To my amazement they worked so well together that if they were to do another film together I could see it happening and would be interested in seeing it.

The premise of the movie has a lot going for it and could turn out to be a great comedy with something we haven't seen before. However, as funny as the movie could be at times it certainly lost that momentum after the first 20 minutes into the film. The set-up of Harts character being the wedding ringer for another client to what his job entails is a great opener. Then we follow Doug who is anxious to death about who his groomsmen are going to be, let alone his best man. And you even get to like his soon to be wife Gretchen, played by Kaley Cuoco-Sweeting, whos character is someone you don't usually see marrying a guy like that of Doug. You could genuinely believe that they were in love with one another and not in a forced manner.

Once Doug and Jimmy begin working together the movie becomes a movie about the journey to the wedding and everything in-between. I will say the groomsmen that Jimmy chose for Doug was essentially the funniest group in the film. They were a combination of criminal, TSA, and a stutterer who all together made for great entertainment. Just watching them take on roles of people made up by Doug was funny because of how opposite they were to their real selves. And I have to mention the lunch scene over at Gretchens parents house. When Doug was about to come clean after not being able to go along with the lie a bowl of chili is dumped on his lap. The trailer made it seem funnier at the time cause of the editing but when it came down to actually watching the scene play out your a little bit underwhelmed. Maybe because wed already seen it in the trailer?

I really like the premise of the film but despite the laughs it becomes a one time viewing that doesnt leave an impression by the end. Seeing Josh Gad and Kevin Hart work together was awesome and shows how great they are together. Potentially we could be seeing more films with them together cause they really hit it off. Overall, audiences will find something to root for in The Wedding Ringer but won't be as good as it couldve been.

Outrageous!  We laughed all the way through this (well, at least most of the way).  This is definitely not a movie for the kids - there is a lot of offensive material, lots of crass humor, and you'll likely find something in there to offend your movie-going companion with.  But this is funny, well-written, has some great cameo-like scenes, and even has some surprising depth to it.

The premise, something many men have probably gone through, or almost wished they could go through, is that the socially awkward groom (Josh Gad) needs a best man (Kevin Hart).  He goes to a company that provides this as a service, and following are all the situations that make it a winner.  There is even some depth of character and relationship between the groom and his new best man.  And in fact, all of his groomsmen, because he hires out the whole team.

Josh Gad was fantastic, what a role for him. He really made the movie, and I think we will be seeing more from him.  Kevin Hart is always funny, and can even turn the occasionally lame gag into something worthwhile.

Do not expect a lot of plot, and recognize this for what it truly is.  Just sit back, relax, and smile - throw your expectations of Oscar winning direction and production out the window, and have a good laugh.

I have always been a fan of these buddy comedies and have been a fan of Kevin Hart since before he blew up. So when this movie came out I knew I would be all about it. I also liked the rest of the cast here so I was looking forward to this flick. So I headed to the theaters to see it and eventually bought this Blu-Ray. Obviously I enjoyed it or I wouldnt have got it.

The story follows a guy named Doug Harris who is getting married to the woman of his dreams. The problem is that he does not have any friends to make up his groomsmen. That is when he learns of a service that will help guys out with that. This company called Best Man Inc. is run by a guy named Jimmy Callahan. He provides everything a guy may need from the groomsmen [himself as best man] to the bachelor party among other things. So as the wedding grows closer the party gets bigger, but things may not go as planned as things fall apart.

This is a very fun movie with a fun cast that all work very well together, you can see the chemistry that they all had with each other. The movie is funny from the cast to the script by writers Jay Lavender and Jeremy Garelick [who also directed] who also wrote The Break Up together. I have to say the best scene in the film is probably the dance scene, love it.

The Blu-Ray comes with behind the scenes stuff, gag reels, deleted scenes, commentary and a great music video by Aloe Blacc. This is recommended to any comedy fan out there that is just looking to shut down and relax. Not the greatest comedy ever made but worth a watch for sure. Now heres on to the next.

I wondered about two things.

(1) What about the issue of the possibility of blackmail?
Any groom who uses this service should worry that, after the wedding, he is in a vulnerable position. Anyone who knew that the best man and groomsmen were fake, including the men themselves, could have blackmailed the groom after the wedding. They could simply go to the groom and demand money from him, or else they will tell the bride and everyone the truth. They could continue asking for more and more money for years.
These were good guys, so they obviously would never do that, but any groom could not know that because these are complete strangers to him. And anyone else who knew the truth could be a blackmailer, not just the men.

(2) What about the possibility that anyone attending these large weddings could recognize the best man or the groomsmen, from other weddings that they may have attended, or from the theme park where they worked, or from anywhere? These large weddings could have a guest who happens to know one of the men.
There actually was a part in the movie where Jimmy realized that the priest knew him, but Jimmy managed to get out of that situation.
But in a large wedding, it would be difficult to avoid anyone recognizing these men.  That is a big risk for the groom to take.

Of course, I am taking the movie too seriously, it is a comedy and it is not supposed to be analyzed, just enjoyed.

As soon as Jimmy said that no one lives in North Dakota, I knew that someone at the wedding would be from North Dakota.

I also guessed that the guy playing the podiatrist would be questioned at the wedding. At least, someone would start asking him medical questions regarding some foot problem, because as soon as people hear that you are a doctor, they want free advice. As I was watching this movie, I kept thinking that the title is such a good play on words, I wonder if the script was just added to fit the title.  In any case, it isn't much more than an opportunity for Kevin Hart to show his comedic skills in a feature film.  He plays Jimmy Callahan, who provides "best man" services to friendless men about to get married.  Not surprisingly, this appears to be a real business.

Doug Harris (Josh Gad) is about to marry a girl "out of his league" by his own accounts.  Gretchen (Kaley Cuoco-Sweeting) is planning a huge wedding and Doug needs a best man and 7 groomsmen.  But he has no friends.  He's made up some for Gretchen, but they don't exist.  So he goes to Jimmy who agrees to do the once in a lifetime "Golden Tux" where he supplies the men, including their scripted alter-egos.

Often the film just goes over the top.  For example, Gretchen's father (Ken Howard) obviously doesn't like Doug, and lures him into a "touch" football game.  You know, he and his old buddies, including characters played by former NFLers Joe Namath, John Riggins and Ed `Too Tall' Jones, against the young upstarts.  Hart and occasionally Gad provide a few good laughs including a funny scene at a "practice wedding" where the duo provide some great dance moves together.  So while Hart can always be hilarious, frankly I'd rather watch him do standup or even a short segment on ESPN's "Mike and Mike."

The Blu ray transfer comes with a 1080p video resolution and a 2.40:1 aspect ratio.  You certainly will have no problem with the look of the film.  Colors are deep, detail is excellent.  Clothing, skin tones are perfect.  This is as good as it gets when it comes to Blu ray.  Audio is provided using DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 and I have no real complaints here either.  It has excellent imaging and enough surround morsels to get noticed, perhaps just a bit too much.  Dialog is well placed, clear and consistent.  Subtitles are available in Spanish, French and English SDH.  Extras include an audio commentary with director Jeremy Garelick and actor Josh Gad, a host of deleted scenes, some outtakes, a music video, shared real life wedding memories by the cast and crew and some Sony trailers.

This was actually a pretty good movie for the most part, but man did they miss every opportunity possible to put a meaningful ending on it. The feelings and resolutions that you want the filmmakers to flesh out and deliver with began to materialize and then landed with a splat and a thud. "The Wedding Ringer" has a lot of good moments for the most part and I enjoyed this movie much more than I thought I would, but it amazes me how often these high-paid millionaire movie-makers mishandle and misdeliver impactful moments in movies.  There's a moment in this film where everything culminates and you can feel the importance of everything you watched the movie for getting ready to be delivered and then just like the scene where the best man goes unscripted with his speech, so does the movie.

This was a good movie and most people won't care that the entire reason for the movie was mishandled when it finally got there, but I did. That being said, the movie has a lot of truth to it, despite its obvious humorous delivery. The premise revolves around Doug Harris, a guy who is marrying a woman because she is beautiful and she talked to him. He has been so buried in work that he has little to no friends and can't seem to form a collection of groomsmen to match his brides (played by Kaley Cuoco) party. So, with the date nearing he reaches out to Jimmy Callahan (Kevin Hart) who has an underground business of pretending to be groomsmen and even best men. The movie plays like a comedic spy caper with dossier's and elaborate event stagings etc and it is all very entertaining and frequently funny.

For the most part, this is a funny and good time wasting film but just be prepared to have everything you watched it for be underwhelming when the time comes.

Face it, Kevin Hart is on a roll when it comes to stardom these days. The stand-up comedian has made it to the big time, moving from ensemble pieces to starring roles these days. But like any stand-up who takes on the big screen there are hits and misses along the way. While this film didn't do huge at the box office perhaps that will turn around with the release on DVD. Once word gets out how funny the movie is its sure to make a splash.

Josh Gad stars as Doug Harris, a man about to marry Gretchen (Kaley Cuoco-Sweeting), the woman of his dreams. The problem is hes represented himself as having plenty of friend when in fact he has none. Even grade school acquaintances are unwilling to show up to be even a groomsman. Two weeks until the wedding Doug is faced with the problem and aided by the wedding planner whos seen this problem before.

Doug is sent to meet with Jimmy Callahan (Hart), a best man for hire. For a fee Jimmy will make sure he has groomsmen, become his best man and plan all the accessories that go along with this event. With the short amount of time and the number of groomsmen involved Jimmy isn't sure he can pull it off. No one in his line of work has ever done a group this big. But hes up to the challenge and sets out to gather a team.

Along the way Jimmy has to know everything he possibly can about Doug, creating more than one backstory to fill in the rest. He also has to learn about Doug so he can create the perfect toast as well as be able to be with him at events like the rehearsal dinner and more. The thing is, even though he stresses to Doug that this is a business arrangement and nothing more, Jimmy finds himself becoming friends with Doug as well.

The humor in this film runs throughout and covers all sorts of styles. The buddy film is evident in the back and forth between Gad and Hart with their friendship taking place quickly but logically as well. There is the gross out humor in the team that Hart assembles with each one having their own quirk. There is the predicament humor found in the situations the duo find themselves in when dealing with Gretchens family (one of the funniest scenes comes from this involving fire and a grandmother played by Cloris Leachman). And then there is the overabundant use of language, perhaps the least funny element in the movie. Dropping the F bomb in a movie 40 years ago might have been surprising and played for laughs but these days its overuse slows things down and doesnt fit right.

Hart has proven that he has the acting chops to carry a movie as the solo lead. This film does him credit in that right as he plays the helping con man who saves the day for guys in need of his services. While he may not seem to care he actually feels for each of the men he helps. Hart makes this believable and thats not easy to do with a character who only knows his client for less than two weeks. Gad also turns in a solid performance here as Doug, a man successful in business but who feels his self-worth is non-existent when it comes to women. Having the chance to marry someone as beautiful as Gretchen seems like a dream come true. Now if he can just get past the wedding.

"God created the world in seven days. We gotta do a whole lot more in a lot less time." Doug Harris (Gad) is getting married but has a problem. Doug doesn't have any friends and needs groomsmen. The previews made it seem funny enough and I really like Josh Gad, but Kevin Hart can sometimes get a little too annoying for me. This is an exception. Hart played it almost perfect and I never once felt like he was too over the top or annoying like in Ride Along. I laughed much more than I was expecting to at this and there is enough types of humor for everyone to find something they will like. There is also enough heart and story in this to keep you interested in what is happening and not just waiting for the next joke. Me and my wife both liked this more than we expected too and this is one of the better comedies to come out in a while. Overall, nothing all that original and pretty predictable but it was very funny and when you rent a comedy that is what you are looking for. To me this is Kevin Hart's best movie I have seen. Kevin Hart always manages to get a laugh out of me in his movies, but this movie was pretty predictable.

***SPOILERS***  ***SPOILERS***  ***SPOILERS***

Right away I could tell that the girlfriend Kaley Cuoco was playing didn't really love our main character and that this was a marriage of convenience for her.  Also I could tell that eventually the cat was going to be let out of the bag and everyone was going to find out that Kevin Hart and Josh Grad's characters didn't really know each other but they were going to be friends by the end of the movie.

Even with this movie being totally predictable, I have to admit that it did get some laughs out of me.  I loved how Kevin Hart and his buddies made up a history with Josh Grad, pretty much in like two days by going around taking photos in crazy places.  And it was also really cool to see Jorge Garcia acting again, I loved him in Lost!  The football game with the old guy vs. the young guys was funny and did make me wince a few times as they were tackling one another.

And at the end we do get a nod to Lost with Jorge Garcia saying he, "Has a bad feeling about this flight."  That was awesome!

***END SPOILERS***  ***END SPOILERS***  ***END SPOILERS***

So like I said before, the movie is very predictable, and it follows the basic format of these buddy movies where two guys are trying to pull off a scheme to fool everyone.  However it does have some good jokes in it and the situational humor is enjoyable.

Overall I'd say this is a movie you rent, not buy.
